The 'pomegranate' , botanical name 'Punica granatum', is a fruit-bearing
deciduous shrub or small tree growing between tall.

The pomegranate is widely considered to have originated in the vicinity of Iran
and has been cultivated since ancient
times. [http://xa.yimg.com/kq/groups/22176678/1153755907/name/Narzary
Analysis of genetic diversity among wild pomegranates in Western Himalayas,
using PCR methods] Retrieved May 5, 2013. http://naldc.nal.usda.gov/d-
ownload/7460/PDF http://om.ciheam.org/om/pdf/a42/00600252.pdf
Today, it is widely cultivated throughout the Mediterranean region of southern
Europe, the Middle East and Caucasus region, northern Africa and tropical
Africa, the Indian subcontinent and the drier parts of southeast Asia. Introduced into Latin America and California by Spanish
settlers in 1769, pomegranate is also cultivated in parts of California and
Arizona.

In the Northern Hemisphere, the fruit is typically in season from September to
February. In the Southern Hemisphere, the pomegranate is in season
from March to May.

The pomegranate has been mentioned in many ancient texts, notably in Babylonian
texts, the Book of Exodus, the Homeric Hymns and the Quran. In recent
years, it has become more common in the commercial markets of North America and
the Western Hemisphere.

Pomegranates are used in cooking, baking, juices, smoothies and alcoholic
beverages, such as martinis and wine. http://www.pomegranatefacts.net/unique-pomegranate-treats-
drinks.html
